title: 103_hr4759
content: The Act may be cited as the "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994". The Congress recognizes the Department of Energy's unique mathematics and science capabilities that contribute to education. There is a need to enhance collaboration between the Department of Energy, other federal agencies, and the mathematics and science education community, which includes nationally recognized teachers. The mathematics and science education community, including outstanding teachers, can provide valuable insight into effective education programs. A pilot program has shown the effectiveness of these teachers serving in professional staff roles in the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Act establishes a national fellowship program for exceptional math and science teachers, known as "Albert Einstein Fellows". Definitions are provided in Section 4. The Act defines key terms such as "contractor" as a nonprofit educational organization administering the fellowship program, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Energy, "elementary school" and "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "outstanding" in relation to teachers. The term "outstanding" for elementary or secondary school math or science teachers is defined as being a State or national winner of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, or having participated in the Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program. Elementary or secondary school mathematics or science teacher defined as a State or national winner of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program participant, or recipient of comparable recognition. Must have received a sabbatical leave to participate in the fellowship program. The individual must be a State or national winner of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, participant in the Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program, or received comparable recognition. They must have taken a sabbatical leave to join the fellowship program. To participate in the fellowship program under this Act, individuals must have taken a sabbatical leave and return to a teaching position in the same school district. The term "secondary school" is defined by the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Fellowship Program is authorized under Section 5 of the Act. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program allows the Secretary to provide 10 outstanding math or science teachers with fellowships each fiscal year, with the possibility of reducing the number of fellowships based on funding availability. The Secretary may reduce the number of fellowships awarded under the Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program in any fiscal year if the appropriated amount is less than the authorized amount. Priority will be given to individuals selected under specific clauses if fellowships are reduced. The Secretary may reduce the number of fellowships awarded under the Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program if the appropriated amount is less than the authorized amount. Priority is given to individuals selected under specific clauses if fellowships are reduced, with 2 teachers awarded fellowships in the Senate and 2 in the House of Representatives. The Secretary shall provide fellowships to 2 outstanding elementary or secondary school mathematics or science teachers in the Senate, 2 in the House of Representatives, and 1 each in the Department of Energy, Department of Education, National Institutes of Health, and National Science Foundation. The Secretary shall provide fellowships to outstanding teachers in the Senate, House of Representatives, Department of Energy, Department of Education, National Institutes of Health, National Science Foundation, Office of Science and Technology Policy, and NASA for a 10-month period. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program provides fellowships for 10 months to outstanding teachers in various government agencies, including the Office of Science and Technology Policy and NASA. The program is administered through a contract with a contractor. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program is administered through a contract with a contractor for the development and administration of the application process for awarding fellowships. The Fellowship Program requires contractors to develop and administer the application process, publicize the program, and screen applicants. The development and administration of an initial screening process for the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program to select outstanding math and science teachers from various recognition programs. The Einstein Fellowship Program selects 10 outstanding math and science teachers for orientation and administration. The Einstein Fellowship Program selects 10 outstanding math and science teachers for orientation, reporting, and evaluation under this Act. The Einstein Fellowship Program selects 10 outstanding math and science teachers for annual reporting and evaluation, including submission of reports to the Secretary and administration of funds received under the Act. The Einstein Fellowship Program selects outstanding math and science teachers for annual reporting, evaluation, and administration of funds received under the Act, including agreements with local educational agencies for fund disbursement. The Einstein Fellowship Program selects exceptional math and science teachers for fellowship awards. Funds are to be used for recipient salaries, insurance contributions, and administrative expenses. The Act allows funding for fellowship recipient salaries, insurance contributions, administrative expenses, orientation program, relocation expenses, and final selection interviews. The contractor can also seek funding from non-Federal sources for travel reimbursements. The contractor can seek funding from non-Federal sources for fellowship recipients' travel, professional meetings, and other expenses. The contractor invites 20 semifinalists to Washington, D.C., for interviews after the initial screening process. The contractor invites 20 semifinalists to Washington, D.C., for interviews after the initial screening process. Final selections are made before May 1 for each fellowship term. The final selections for fellowship recipients are made before May 1 for each term. The Speaker of the House, Minority Leader, Majority Leader of the Senate, and their designees each select a recipient for assignment to either the House of Representatives or the Senate. The Speaker and Minority Leader of the House, along with the Majority Leader and Minority Leader of the Senate, or their designees, select fellowship recipients for assignment to either the House of Representatives or the Senate. The Secretary of Energy, Secretary of Education, and Director of the National Institutes of... The Majority Leader and Minority Leader of the Senate, or their designees, each select a fellowship recipient for assignment to the Senate. Additionally, the Secretary of Energy, Secretary of Education, Director of the National Institutes of Health, Director of the National Science Foundation, Assistant to the President for Science and Technology Policy, and Administrator of NASA, or their designees, each select one fellowship recipient. Each selected individual for a fellowship will be assigned within the department, agency, institute, or office that they are chosen for. Fellowship recipients will interview in various sections, offices, or divisions within the department. Each individual selected for a fellowship will be placed within the department, agency, institute, or office they are chosen for. The final placement process involves interviewing in different sections, offices, or divisions within the organization before the fellowship period begins. Each fellowship recipient will be paid at a rate not exceeding GS-13 of the General Schedule. $550,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1995, with additional funds for 1996-2001 to implement the Act.
